As a BDR, your opinion and feedback usually mean nothing

job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Burlington, MA
pros: It's a solid SAAS / IAAS / Tech sales foundation. This is 101 and 201 out of the BDR program and you will learn if you are a right fir for Oracle or if you will find success at most other companies. The Oracle sales model is an esoteric bundling of overlapping teams where it becomes easy to lose sight of the customer unless you're highly collaborative and willing to sell your own interests internally before ever becoming part of true customer relationships. It is difficult to maintain coherence of Oracle's brand ownership but if all the overlapping teams are able to coordinate effectively, they become a deal-making machine. It is all a numbers game, internally and externally. If this type of sales does not suit you, then you can walk onto most other sales roles because of the excellent training and development resources that resemble more of an academy than onboarding.
cons: Either Oracle's way of doing business works for you, or it does not. If you want autonomous control of being the brand representative for your accounts as you are trained to be, then you will find that in a direct sales role at most other cloud services company.

review_title: Valuable experience overall where you learn and grow through painful experiences.
pros:
High end in job training
Variable compensation IF you get a good patch
cons:
No recognition for achievements, SVP that encourage you to do malpractice activities, threatens you on sundays.
No vision, no mission, the only value and only objective is short term money, regardless of clients needs and common long term business.

Also, for a so called technologie leaders, you should see the stupid processes that we have to go through to get anything done. You spend more time talking to different layers of management and deal with some very user friendly systems than building relationship and selling value & experience to your customer/prospect.

Although lots of very competent IC’s, management is a mix of very good/experienced and terrible toxic counter productive short term personal career oriented “leader”.

Pay attention to your initial négociation, because once accepted you package is likely to evolve very slowly.

Not only you’ll have to perform (obvious) but you’ll also have to deal with complex situation were management is asking you to work for “free” or encourage you to do malpractice activities.

job_title: Principal Technical Support Engineer in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Free drinks in the break room - Except, COVID - so, really, not many. There are *some* good people left, but that is more a reflection of the people than the company.
cons:
Quick to RIF when their "numbers" are not matched. Process adherence is only used asa beating stick with those who are not "pals" with management - the metrics are faked/massaged/fudged to the point of falsehood and irrelevance, yet still used for "business decisions" and to make managers "look good" (I hit my numbers! See? Are you not entertained?). Very shady and unethical. Engineers told to "play in the grey area" on a weekly basis.

If you're looking for real, objective performance reviews on an annual basis or even cost-of-living increases, go elsewhere - the "reviews" are a checkbox exercise for managers, and nothing is invested in the professional growth of a top-talent individual. 

Pay? Right - they pay the minimum - far below the industry average.

Upper-Management Integrity? Nope - they will either obscure the facts or flat-out lie to a customer just to make themselves look better. This is across the boards, all management teams, as if they have a mandate from above their pay grade to do so.

tl;dr - This is where careers go to die. Avoid at all costs.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Burlington, MA
pros: Oracle is a large company that for the most part takes care of it's employees. In a sales role there is definitely a bit of luck of the draw when initially taking over a territory. However, for the most part there is opportunity to make money if you work hard and do a good job of building relationships with your accounts. Don't buy into the hype of "it's not a good territory so I can't make money" because the person before you that had the territory may not have been good. The group of people I'm currently working for at Oracle are some of the best people I've ever worked for and truly care about their people. Overall it's a good company to work for and allows you to build a resume to move onto other strong companies if that's what you want or move up the ranks within Oracle.
cons:
Coming into Oracle you don't have a choice of who you work for and there is a big difference between the good and bad managers at Oracle. 
Filling open territories isn't always done in the fairest/best manner. For example: you may have someone leave a territory that is a very good one and rather than offer that to a hard working team member that currently doesn't have the best territory they often hand it to a new rep.

job_title: Consulting Member of Technical Staff in Burlington, MA
pros: Depending on which department you are in you can expect interesting work, high-calibre colleagues, great flexibility, and pretty decent benefits.
cons: There are some pretty burdensome centralized processes that make it difficult at times to get what should be straightforward tasks done efficiently. You may start off with a good salary, but once you're in, no matter how outstanding your contributions, don't expect decent raises. After almost 20 years of work there, with outstanding reviews, I just got a 1.7% raise this year -- the first one in almost five years.

review_title: A customer centric company does not start from the customers, it starts from the CEO
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for Oracle are you have really great people with a lot of experience, and depending on the team, but generally people are very nice and there is a friendly atmosphere. Great name for your CV, Oracle is one of the best known companies in the world and they have a vast number of resources available to employees. You can move internally to different countries, there are many volunteering opportunities and you can work with some of the best companies as your clients. There is also a lot of learning available, courses and all is paid for by the company. So overall these stand out as the positive.
cons: There is, unfortunately a toxic culture, this means that you have to sell sell sell at no cost, even if you are selling your customer something that is not needed you will try to push this as this is the style and what is it shown internally. There is little to no room for salary improvement, I have been there for more than 3 years and there is no rise unless you change your job/department completely and even though that would be minimal raise. The company is fragmented and layered, you barely get the customers view to top management because they just wont listen, completely hierarchical.

review_title: Meat factory - but good place to get your foot in the tech industry door
pros: The Oracle culture felt like a frat house. If your into college 2.0, this could be the place for you. They dont do a lot of talent vetting, so if you dont have any hard skills and want to sharpen those soft skills of yours; look no further. Great employee comradery birthed from everyone hating their job.
cons: You wont do as much selling as you will auditing customers and strong arming them into buying products that dont work and they dont want. Essentially the Wiseguys of the Techworld.

review_title: A customer centric company does not start from the customers, it starts from the CEO
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for Oracle are you have really great people with a lot of experience, and depending on the team, but generally people are very nice and there is a friendly atmosphere. Great name for your CV, Oracle is one of the best known companies in the world and they have a vast number of resources available to employees. You can move internally to different countries, there are many volunteering opportunities and you can work with some of the best companies as your clients. There is also a lot of learning available, courses and all is paid for by the company. So overall these stand out as the positive.
cons: There is, unfortunately a toxic culture, this means that you have to sell sell sell at no cost, even if you are selling your customer something that is not needed you will try to push this as this is the style and what is it shown internally. There is little to no room for salary improvement, I have been there for more than 3 years and there is no rise unless you change your job/department completely and even though that would be minimal raise. The company is fragmented and layered, you barely get the customers view to top management because they just wont listen, completely hierarchical.

review_title: Meat factory - but good place to get your foot in the tech industry door
pros: The Oracle culture felt like a frat house. If your into college 2.0, this could be the place for you. They dont do a lot of talent vetting, so if you dont have any hard skills and want to sharpen those soft skills of yours; look no further. Great employee comradery birthed from everyone hating their job.
cons: You wont do as much selling as you will auditing customers and strong arming them into buying products that dont work and they dont want. Essentially the Wiseguys of the Techworld.
